Whoa, wait a minute. Mercenaries did NOT end serfdom.
The Black Death ended serfdom, IMO. The 50% mortality caused a shortage of labor.
That shortage caused a demand for labor --- lords would poach "serfs" from other estates.
The lords could no longer enforce serf conditions. They became free.
Thus, they could become mercenaries, or artisans, or tradesmen.
Thus, the Black Death brought about the end of the Middle Ages and brought on the Renaissance.
Just as Thanos predicted, a 50% loss of population can be a good thing. (well, except for the people who died that is.)

Fun Fact! about the Black Death in the UK we had Plague doctors (not sure in they were all over Europe). They weren't actually doctors but were paid a high amount to deal with the victims of the plague in any way, and it was expected by the government that a lot would die. However due to their uniform (google it, it is so strange looking) they actually have a better chance of living than normal people as their cloak's were made of such heavy and thick material fleas couldn't get in easily and infect them; so a lot more lived then what the government would have liked so they tried there best not to pay them.

Fun Fact 2! if you did get the disease in medieval times you had a better chance of survival if you got the bubonic plague then any other type as the method of treatment was cutting off the Buboes (the lumps) and sealing it shut with a hot poker. But due to the pain, and the fact that you still had a high chance of dying, not a lot of people took that option.

John, I've been a big fan of your Crash Course History videos since the original World History and US History series'. You've done a great job talking about history as complex and nuanced, while making it digestible to a general audience.


However I do want to contest the titling of this video as "Medieval Europe." As you've mentioned in other videos (I believe the Dark Ages one in the original World History series), the so-called "Middle Ages" in Europe lasted for about 1000 years, give or take, so it's not entirely coherent to paint with such a broad brush as "in the Middle Ages" or "in Medieval times." In other words, the actual "Medieval period" lasts for about twice as long as the time period this entire series intends to cover. There are also several claims in this video that are certainly true for the 14th and 15th centuries, but provably false for earlier centuries in the Medieval period-- namely the emphasis on the prevalence of death by warfare and starvation. I guess in the grand scheme of things, this is a minor complaint, but is one that could be addressed.


Anyway, thanks so much for the work you do. I'm excited to see how this series unfolds!


-A lifelong Crash Course Fan

I take issue with several parts of the information presented in this video: 1. It starts at the end of the period known as the High Middle Ages 1100-1300, an important and most misunderstood window of time; 2. Misses the Investiture Controversy of 1075, itself arguably tracing its origins to the Pope's crowning of Charlemagne in 800, a single act which gave the Bishop of Rome precedents over secular leadership, fast forwarding to 1303, kidnapping of Pope Bonaface VIII was a reaction to his excommunication of all of France as well as King Philip IV, the kidnapping is believed to have been a Thomas Beckett moment, whereby supporters of the French King burst into the Papal Palace and attempted to drag the Pope Bonaface to Philip's territory, so he might be subject to the French Crown, by so doing forcing him to absolve the Excommunication. He was very old and died more of shock shortly after. There is little evidence that Philip IV had anything to do with it, but he went with it upon learning about it; 4 this video is too Anglocentric, the greatest peasant revolt accord in Germany in the 1460s; 5 the rise of the Hanseatic League of Northern Europe and the typically neglected and shamefully overlooked Kingdom of Poland.

The Middle Ages never existed, it is an invented concept which dating from the early renaissance humanist Leonardo Bruni 1370-1444, who in his famed "Historiarum Florentini", a collection of historiography, categorised civilisation into 3 Ages. This has continued to be the way we few the timeline of Western Civilisation, with early-modern historiographers casting Rome's decline as a dramatic fall and casting the subsequent centuries, that they were ignorant of, as a "dark age" and a scapegoat for much that is wrong with humanity.
The time between A.D. 453(final sack of Rome) – circa 1500, was one of rapid change, with hardly a quarter century passing in abscense of alteration, which cannot be said for periods of Greece and Rome. Several core aspects define the pseudo-period, notably Christendom, fiefdoms, a decentralisation of authority and the continue of some created institutions such as Royal Crowns of France, England, et cetera and the succeeding of families transmitting titles and property through generations.

As a medieval history graduate student, I find that, while this video was quite informative, it does fail to provide a clear understanding of the medieval world. I understand that these videos are supposed to be for a high school level classes but it demonstrates the key problems of teaching the Middle Ages. There is a tendency towards focusing on the worst episodes of the period, which admittedly there are a lot of. However, there is a lot that is lost when looking at these episodes. The medieval world was exceptionally complicated and was filled with highs and lows for people of all classes. Sure there was strife and corruption in the church but they also supported the works of scholars like Roger Bacon and Thomas Aquinas. Engineers were tasked with creating weapons of war but they also created great cathedrals that, from an architectural standpoint, rival that of the greeks and romans. Plague devastated the population of Europe but the people that survived kept going and did let this disaster break them. People underestimate the complexity of the medieval world and are willing to use Monty Python as there source for imagining the period. But this misses out on an era that reminds me that no matter how horrible things are, people survive, thrive and make incredible things. I hope some day you might do a Crash Course Medieval History because there is so much more to the Middle Ages beyond plague, war and schisms.

Burgundy was a DUCAL court, not a royal court. Though there was a Kingdom of Burgundy, it had been absorbed by the Holy Roman Empire about half a millenium prior (technically the Holy Roman Emperors were kings of Germany, Italy and Burgundy until 1806, but de facto those titles had long dissolved). However as Imperial power over its western fringe slowly declined several regions, including Burgundy, fell under control of France.

The Dukes of Burgundy were, even during the 100 Years' War, technically vassals of the French king, but as royal authority was weak due to that whole "other kings want to ursurp our throne" deal the Dukes of Burgundy were de facto a sovereign realm seeking full independency from the French crown, especially after they inherited significant territories in the Low Countries as the Dukes of Bavaria-Straubing went extinct. Fun fact: Through marriage these Burgundian Low Countries fell first to Austria and then to Castile/Spain before a minor noble from western Germany led these provinces into revolt and thus founded the precursor of what is now the Kingdom of the Netherlands.

I think we all know that the real cause of the black death was China opening up the silk road and thereby breaking their isolationism.


But wait... The Han Dynasty only opened the Silk road because they wanted to spread Chinese culture to the Tarim basin. And they only wanted to do that because the Tarim Basin was paying tribute to the Xiongnou nomads who were ravaging China and extracting Chinese tribute. And they hoped that by spreading Chinese culture and encouraging trade they could break the Tarim Basin from the Xiongnou empire (and it worked). History is so beautifully complex.

The Black Death's economic effects are really cool - it led to a rise in wages (obviously, because so many people had died), and led to a huge rise in the amount of decadent spending; we hear descriptions of crowns that were worn by kings and dukes only once then melted down afterwards into something else entirely!

And related to beer, some have theorised it led to experimentation in the field of brewing, because farmers were still growing the same amount of crops as beforehand, but for a markedly smaller population, leading ultimately to better alcohol! Though I'm a bit cynical on that one :)

At some point during this course it would be interesting to reflect on the Great Divergence between Europe and the rest of the civilised world, that started precisely around the period between 1450 and 1500. Before that time, Europe had been stagnant during more than 1000 years, you could say that living in Europe in the year 1300 was worse than living in China or in the Muslim world, or that it was worse than living in the Roman Empire in the year 200. But after 1500 the Renaissance started, and after that the Enlightenment, and after that the Industrial Revolution, and then the second Industrial Revolution, ant then the third, all of that in Europe or in north America in a sort of chain reaction. So I hope that this Crash Course helps explain why that Great Divergence started in Europe at that particular moment in history and not anywhere else.

I love you guys, but it bothers me a little that you're using the EU flag and the EU's colours on the title card and cutscenes. And I say that as someone who's pro-EU!

The EU contains only 27/28 of the ~50 countries of Europe. And it's only existed for the last 26 years of nearly 2000 years of recorded history. It's like using the US flag for Crash Course North & Central American History.

I'm British, and our country has been thoroughly European since the beginning - we started as western european Celts and were heavily influenced by a sequence of Roman, Germanic, Nordic and Norman French invaders. We've cooperated, traded, and warred with our neighbours for close to a millennium. And as you know, the royal houses of Europe were so linked by the 20th century that the monarchs of the major powers in the first world war were cousins.

We were European long before the EU was founded, and we'll continue to be just as European even if the Brexiteers succeed in dragging us out of it.

A bit disappointed by this Episode. The content itself is fine, but the framing seems to be accepting the notion of the Progress Narrative. I liked how John Green seemed to question the validity of the using terms like "the Middle Ages." I liked what he said about drinkable water, and about the grass roots organization of peasants. All this was fine. I have issues with how John Green spoke about disease in Medieval times, and then used the Black Death as the only example. The Black Death was terrible and it completely destroyed guild institutions and medication orders. But this should be taken in the context of how life was like before this. In other words, this video mainly focuses on the Late Middle Ages without giving it the framing of the Early and High Middle Ages. This video should have been labeled "Medieval Europe in the Late Middle Ages." I'm hoping that there will be other videos that go more in-depth about the Middle Ages, but this video seems to be setting up either a video about the Renaissance or 14th century humanism with Petrarch. Again, the content is nuanced and fine, but the framing could come across as problematic  to medievalist historians. Admittedly, I am just an undergraduate history major, but I have studied High Middle Age Medieval Europe quite extensively (for an undergrad, that is). I feel that an episode on guilds, universities, saints, the Church, proto-science, the inquisitions, crusades, herbalists, snd magic, are needed for context.

I usually liked everything you did so far, but sorry guys, you missed something important here:

There is no way to even begin something, that resembles 'understanding the middle ages and/or any thing else about Europe, or 'western history' in general, without at least giving the setup by mentioning:

- the split of the roman empire
- the EARLY christian Schisms
- how damn long it took the followers of, what became 'the only true faith' by principle of elimination, to 'convince' those 'heretics' & hedons' of their great idea that a pope in rome should rule the half dozen or so kings, they managed to 'mission' around the Rhine River, which in turn should rule entire europe. (c.a. 900)
- who those heretics and hedons where and what happened to them (and mentioning how many of those 'hedons' where believers and followers of that exact same Jesus, could help a lot in avoiding, stepping on someones feelings there).
- what feudalism looked like before they managed that
- what 'common goods' where and how that could have been of importance
- and ___THOMAS D' AQUIN___??? (c.a. 1220)

it would also help to mention, that the byzantine empire and most likely everyone else, as long as they could, where perfectly capable to keep there history straight and not only maintain their civilization, but actually improve up on it by roughly the amount one would expect in a Millenia. How at the same time 'the medieval people' lost the ability to make cement & mortar and had to stack reused bricks on top of each other, held together by dung (cow s--t) and how little that had to do with availability of ancient volcanic ash. How everyone was supposed to stay home at all times unless explicitly ordered to die in some stupid war about which highly degenerated descendant of whom, shook whichever roman emperors, hand at some point in time, or didn't (or what we refer to as 'history' ever since then). That every Crafts Master and Journeyman, as well as every merchant HAD to be able to travel, read, write and do math, or even worse, geometry. and what 'tommy the dummy' thought about all of that and about all the other things, that nutjob of a 'greatest and most important 'philo(no...can't type that)' considered harmful. How such ideas as 'water makes sinful thoughts' might have effect seven pest epidemics in a row and what general effecte that type of thinking could have in such a desperate situation, especially if brutally enforced by the freshly made up 'inquisition'. Why everyone (unfortunately including you), keeps insisting on choosing an arbitrary point right around that time where that variant of the medieval story 'starts' and why that's considered normal by definition.

sorry having let this one out on you guys, since you did such great work before. But that also kind of raised my expectations. I do actually understand, why technically speaking, those 'details' I deem so important are not considered 'history' by definition. But it took me over thirty years to understand that. I tried to wrap my head around the middle ages, a couple of times and usually just gave up, because nothing makes any sense at all! It took hundreds of hours of reading up things on Wikipedia, years of prior interest in Sociology, Antropology, Archaeology and so much more. YouTube channels and playlists turned out to be enormously helpful. Many of those where produced by you guys! So who if not you, could at least mention why history just stopped making sense and stayed complicated, weird and broken, from around those 'dark ages' on and hasn't made sense ever since? How 'nation states', as we know them, are not naturally appearing Phaenomena.

'Tommy the dummy's' work and the school of thought, he stands for distorted christianitie, reformation and enlightenment alike, had terrible consequences and haunts us to the day, whenever someone opens her, or his mouth, to state "It has to be true, because I really, really wan't it to be and you have to believe it too, so I don't feel threatened by you, or I will have to harm you", which in some form, or another seems to happen a lot lately.

The Council of Constance mentioned in the video (although not by name) was a really interesting event. Beside the schism, it also delt (or attempted to) with the Bohemian (Czech) precursor of the Reformation - Jan Huss and the conflict of Poland and Lithuania with the Teutonic Order. The former mater caused a period of great turmoil in the Kingdom of Bohemia, known as the Hussite Wars, which is no less interesting than the Hundred Years War in my opinion, while the latter inspired diplomatic, legal and theologic debate that included Polish intellectuals; Paulus Vladimiri (Paweł Włodkowic) and Stanisław of Skarbimierz advocating ideas of religious tolerance, international law and universal human rights.

While I agree that the Black Death is a better jumping off point for European history than the usual choices of Fall of The Roman Empire or Charlemagne, I'm disappointed that you missed WHY it's such a good jumping off point. The Black Death completely and utterly destroyed the civilization that Europe had developed before it, with it's abundance of food, cheap labour, and strong central authorities. The (mentioned) Ciompi movement, the (unmentioned) Hanseatic League, Windmills, Plate Armour, and Renaissance Humanism are all a direct result of the massive reevaluation of human life (not just noble life!) caused by the Black Death. I cannot overstate how big of a deal this is.

I also feel that you are remiss in not mentioning the disintegration of the Holy Roman Empire. This loss of central authority created the conditions for (among other things) the rise of the Hapsburg Dynasty, Protestant Reformation, 30 and 80 Years' wars. That state of affairs almost singularly defined the next 400 years of European history. Also Hussites.

I get that Crash Course is intended to be able to be used in a classroom, but it's sort of a shame you guys are doing this series when that's already 99% of what people are taught about history. I think you guys would have done way more of a public service by doing a series, on, say, the history of India & Southeast Asia, or The Americas: These have thousands of years of history of complex civilization yet aside from the parts that involve Europeans, basically nothing about them is taught.
People also vastly underestimate the amount of records we have for those : For Mesoamerica we have hundreds of examples of inscriptions detailing the political histories of Classical Maya kingdoms, and hundreds of Aztec language documents and a few ten's from other cultures and civilizations (Such as the Mixtec, Purepecha, Postclassic Maya, etc) during the period of European contact which goes in great depth about their societies and the past few hundred years of history. That, combined with the Archeological records from the prior 2000-2500 years of Mesoamerican civilization, and the Archeological records from the Andes (the Inca, Moche, Chimu, etc) would probably be enough for a full Crash Course series; and for India and SEA, they have tons of surviving records.
